body:
> Integrity is a part of security, not "security" if you ask me. If I only give you integrity, it is not "secure". That is what I'm implying.

Okay. That's not how I would use those terms, but I now understand what you were saying. Thanks for clarifying. Hopefully you understood where I was coming from also (using integrity as a type of security, and not a component of security).

Semantics of "security" now hopefully resolved, I'm still concerned about the removal of an enforcement of an integrity "best-practice". What is the use case/driving force for removing this enforcement?

> What is the use case/driving force for removing this enforcement?

I have a truststore which doesn't have a password and I cannot configure Accumulo to use SSL. Cut and dry.

The other things you suggested seem like fine other things that could be pursued.

> I have a truststore which doesn't have a password

Can't a password be set on the truststore to add integrity to it? That seems better (and easier) than changing the code base to relax the integrity constraint.

> That seems better (and easier) than changing the code base to relax the integrity constraint.

I disagree.

I was lurking around in the Accumulo monitor code and Jetty code to understand this.  One thing I noticed in the Jetty code is that if the truststore is not set, then it will use the keystore as the truststore.  So one possible option is we require both truststore path and password are set OR no truststore props are set.  When nothing is set for the truststore, then we don't set anything on Jetty's SslConnectionFactory for truststore and it falls back to the keystore.

I think an issue needs to be opened about the monitor falling back to http if https config is present but incorrect.  The monitor should probably fail to start.

> So one possible option is we require both truststore path and password are set OR no truststore props are set. When nothing is set for the truststore, then we don't set anything on Jetty's SslConnectionFactory for truststore and it falls back to the keystore.

I'm not following how this helps my case, Keith. I have a truststore with no password. I don't want the keystore to be used.

> I disagree.

Okay... so ease is subjective and we disagree on which is easier. Either way, I'm still concerned about potentially relaxing an integrity constraint without sufficient justification, even if it is slightly easier.

You've requested my opinion, and my opinion is that stores without this integrity check put users at greater risk and we shouldn't let users shoot themselves in the foot like that. I don't think this risk justifies whatever ease of use comes from avoiding setting a password to add an integrity check to the store (which can be done by running the simple command `keytool -storepasswd -keystore my.truststore`). Even if the risk is small, I think the ease of use benefit is smaller.

I'm not convinced that you've made a case that this ease does justify the risks, but I'm willing to hear you out if you wish to make such a case. Otherwise, feel free to proceed with my objection outstanding. I won't veto or block it... I just think it's a bad idea. Even if you do merge this change, I will continue to recommend people use passphrases on their truststores, for whatever extra integrity checking it enables.

> I'm not following how this helps my case, Keith. I have a truststore with no password. I don't want the keystore to be used.

Ok.  I suggested because I suspected the truststore was created because it was required and duplicated CA info already in the keystore.  But that is not your use case, so ignore that line of thought. 

I think there two distinct issues to consider with this change : password quality and was a password set.  It may make sense to require setting a password.  However, nothing should be baked into the code that attempts to measure password quality and reject bad passwords.  If we are going to disallow empty string, then why stop there?  Why not also disallow single character passwords?  

In the 2.0 branch I think I added something to AccumuloConfig to check if a prop was set or not, but I don't think this is in 1.9.  If there is an easy way to distinguish between set and not set in 1.9, then I think requiring the user to set any password (including empty string) would be good.  If this solution is not easy to do in 1.9, then I don't have strong opinion for or against making this change as is.

> Ok. I suggested because I suspected the truststore was created because it was required and duplicated CA info already in the keystore. But that is not your use case, so ignore that line of thought.

Gotcha. No, that's not the case here.

> I think there two distinct issues to consider with this change : password quality and was a password set.

This strikes me as a future improvement. Mine is specifically targeted to this one scenario which prevents me from enabling TLS. Your suggestion, as well as Christopher's, sound like good other improvements to consider.

There's currently no way to distinguish between set empty and unset, as is. Disallowing an empty passphrase is consistent with the behavior of `keytool`, which requires a passphrase of at least 6 characters. If we were to allow it, we should at least spit out a warning that we cannot verify its integrity.

> If we were to allow it, we should at least spit out a warning that we cannot verify its integrity.

How about 086268b @ctubbsii ?

> How about [086268b](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/commit/086268b1915fcef9e2c6d1d984db6449d7e17b53) @ctubbsii ?

I still think it's a bad idea to encourage/support lack of integrity on the truststore, but I'm more comfortable with the warning being present.

This seems to have gotten merged with outstanding build failures and without closing the PR. I did my best to resolve the failures, but @keith-turner , do you know what's going on with this? Did it accidentally get merged too early? Or the wrong branch get merged? There now appears to be conflicts.
@ctubbsii  I squashed, merged, resolved conflicts, ran mvn compile, and pushed.  I should have run mvn verify.  Thanks for fixing it.
The accumulo shell has a `du` command that takes one or more table names as an argument.   If given multiple tables, it will compute the amount of overlapping space which is useful for cloned tables.
PS, I'm still fighting a deterministic unit test failure in TServerUtilsTest where the original port grabbed doesn't actually preclude the second from grabbing the same...

> ServerSocket[addr=0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0,localport=1024]

Seems like the newer Thrift is to blame, or just TServerUtilsTest. We only pass in the port at TServerUtils.java:279 when constructing the `TServerSocket` which results in the test not binding to localhost as expected. I think this is why it doesn't fail.

How doesn't this fail for everyone though?
Well, at this point, this is obviously not something related to this change. Will spin this out.
FWIW, I don't see this on my linux server, and I can only assume that the rest of you don't see this either. Your guess is as good as mine why my osx machine does...

I assume from the approvals that y'all aren't too worried with the "why"? Sufficiently straightforward at a glance?

I made the change in the SASL server binding because it did the same thing as the BlockingServerSocket. However, the NonBlockingServerSocket impl was doing it right.

> I assume from the approvals that y'all aren't too worried with the "why"? Sufficiently straightforward at a glance?

My assumption looking at the changes is that it was not binding to the correct interface because the host was ignored.  Is this correct?   I grepped the code for usages of TServerSocket when reviewing.

I have no idea why it only failed on OSX.

> I made the change in the SASL server binding because it did the same thing as the BlockingServerSocket. However, the NonBlockingServerSocket impl was doing it right.

When grepping for TServerSocket I also noticed address is passed to `TSSLTransportFactory.getServerSocket`.  I assumed this code is doing the right thing w.r.t to interface binding.

I think this was cherry-picked from 1.9 to 2.0. Typically, we apply to the oldest branch and merge forward to newer branches, to ensure whatever we've patched in older releases aren't regressed in newer ones.

> My assumption looking at the changes is that it was not binding to the correct interface because the host was ignored. Is this correct?

When stepping through the test in a debugger, I saw that it was bound to "0.0.0.0" instead of the localhost the unit test passed in. That was enough to give me some confidence how it happened.
Crap, I forgot about that. Will push a merge.
Nevermind, you did this.

I recall we had some weird logic in there somewhere that looked for cases where the address was "0.0.0.0" and then tried to figure out the host for the localhost itself. Passing in the hostname directly, when we have it makes sense to me; maybe we can avoid that dubious logic. As to why it might have happened on Mac only, Linux has a "myhostname" name service for /etc/nsswitch.conf that facilitates reverse lookup of the local hostname. Maybe that might help explain why it didn't fail on Linux, but I haven't done a deep dive.

The change looks correct to me... passing in the hostname explicitly. If this results in weird behavior with bind address, I'm sure we'll catch and fix that before release. I'm not worried.
Ok, thanks all. Will wait for Jenkins to pass then push.
Yeah, not a big deal to fix. I just wanted to mention it to serve a reminder (especially to any newcomer observers). :smiley_cat:
thank you ! I will try it.
Changes were merged into master closing #573
Closed by PR #575

> Why replace Connector with AccumuloClient? These are consequential changes and I found myself wondering if this could be done in 2.1.0.

I was going off of improvements @mikewalch had already made to Connector.  With the creation of new builder methods to make it easier to use, it made sense to do it now and put them in a new class.  It was an easy way to separate new changes and create an opportunity to have something better than Connector.

> With the creation of new builder methods to make it easier to use, it made sense to do it now and put them in a new class.

Ok, so if its not done now then it can't be done later without also deferring the new builder methods?

> create an opportunity to have something better than Connector.

The changes are really nice, it will make newly written Accumulo code look a lot nicer.  I hope we keep Connector around for a long time though to support existing code since it has been the only way to write Accumulo code since 2011.

> Ok, so if its not done now then it can't be done later without also deferring the new builder methods?

Yeah that is what I was thinking.  If we release the new builder methods as a part of Connector, than they would have to be deprecated as well.  If we like the new AccumuloClient class, then it saves work to do it now.

> I hope we keep Connector around for a long time though

I agree.  Deprecating Connector here is purely for informing users "Hey we created a new API a bit cleaner and more clear".  I don't see why we can't keep Connector around indefinitely, since its unlikely that something in it prevents future changes or is a problem.

for master branch, I believe this functionality moved to [accumulo-testing](https://github.com/apache/accumulo-testing) and changed enough that there's no longer an environment variable that causes a cli option to be passed for the debug log location, so I did a `-sours` merge.
Any more feedback for this PR?  It has been up for almost two weeks so I will merge after today if no objections.
the relevant change is going from `FileSystem.get(conf)` to `FileSystem.getLocal(conf)`; the formatting changes were done by maven.

Can you add a description to the commit (and to this PR) explaining a justification? Does it not help to add it to the distributed cache? Is the distributed cache an unstable API? What's the benefit?

I'm probably okay with this happening... I just think the rationale should be explained a bit to justify the change.
@ctubbsii, i updated the description

Check out [bulkver1](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/tree/master/server/master/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/master/tableOps/bulkVer1) and [bulkver2](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/tree/master/server/master/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/master/tableOps/bulkVer2)

It would be like those packages but one for each operation in [FateOperation](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/master/thrift/FateOperation.java)

So TABLE_BULK_IMPORT and TABLE_BULK_IMPORT2 are already done, that is what [bulkver1](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/tree/master/server/master/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/master/tableOps/bulkVer1) and [bulkver2](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/tree/master/server/master/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/master/tableOps/bulkVer2) cover.
It would probably be easiest to start with one FateOperation and open a pull request first to make sure we are on the same page.  Then you could do a second PR for the rest.

Doesn't this make it a bit harder for the average user to know what public API is? I wouldn't have thought we had a problem with a sprawling public API (actually would've said we're pretty darn good at a minimal one).

I prefer the public API being declared in the README, not the Javadoc. Javadoc is a pain to maintain, and I think its use should be limited to describing API semantics of the specific, narrowly-scoped class, method, field, or even package it is attached to. Further, it is intended to be viewed in a rendered form... not raw HTML embedded inside a Java comment. Linking from the README to the Accumulo.java file isn't doing users any favors.

Also, I'm pretty sure there's no reason to turn off checkstyle for the javadoc. That's just asking for trouble, potentially introducing rendering issues that should have been caught earlier.

As for the class move, I think that's fine, although ultimately, I'd prefer the main entry point be in a separate API jar, so the API definition is just "everything accessible in accumulo-api.jar", but that will take more work to avoid dependency cycles between jars.

I thought of another reason why the README pointing to the Accumulo.java file is... the README is also for consumers of the binary tarball... which does not contain the Accumulo.java file. If we move the public API information to the javadoc, we'd have to have a different README for the binary and source tarballs.

At this point, I think the case is pretty strong to keep the public API statement in the README. @keith-turner What do you think?

> Doesn't this make it a bit harder for the average user to know what public API is?

Possibly, its hard to know w/o data.   I am not convinced the readme is better place for new devs to find this critical piece of information.  My thinking was that javadoc is something that developers read in their IDE, therefore its important we define the API there.  I had two goals for this javadoc that I thought new developers were likely to read:

  * Define the public API
  * Help new developers find other top level API entry points 

>  the README is also for consumers of the binary tarball... which does not contain the Accumulo.java file

Thats a good point.   Based on these comments I think the following would be a better solution than defining the API in Readme.md or Accumulo.java.

  * Define the API on the website at a place where it has a stable link, like https://accumulo.apache.org/api.   
  * Link to this definition from README.md, Accumulo.java, Accumulo Tour, Accumulo User manual, and any other docs written for developers.  

I took a quick look at the tour and the user manual section on writing clients and did not see mention of the API.  We could make all of these places link to the README on github, but I think linking to https://accumulo.apache.org/api is more elegant.  This way we can avoid trying to decide the one place that would be most beneficial to place this info, instead link to it from any documentation written for new developers.

> I took a quick look at the tour and the user manual section on writing clients and did not see mention of the API. We could make all of these places link to the README on github, but I think linking to https://accumulo.apache.org/api is more elegant.

I like this a lot.  I found it difficult when writing the tour to have a simple way of explaining what is API and what is not.  This way, we could just link to the API web page.

I think a single web page devoted to the API would be perfect. We can link to it from the javadoc and readme and even have a link on the main page.

> We can link to it from the javadoc and readme and even have a link on the main page.

I think a link on the main page is ok as long as it does not clutter.   Even if there is a link on the main page, I still think explicit links in docs for new devs are important to guide new users to this important info.

I thought the README was a pretty stable location already, but obviously, it's limited in the amount of details we should put there so it doesn't get bloated. A dedicated central place on the website is fine with me.

> A dedicated central place on the website is fine with me.

+1, as long as it's "human readable" and prominent, I think it's fine. My experience is that folks do not venture into Javadoc unless they have a very specific question.

> A dedicated central place on the website is fine with me.

I can create PRs for the website and code to make this change.  I will leave this PR open until subsequent PRs or issues are created.  I'll hold off on working on it until @joshelser has had a chance to respond to this proposed change.
Just saw the comment from @joshelser after posting.  I'll get started on this.

@ctubbsii http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net/config_modifier.html
Thanks @cjmctague It looks like the redundant modifier rule is what we want. It'd be great if the eclipse formatter also had something so they automatically get removed.

@keith-turner I used IntelliJ to analyze and find them.

@ctubbsii I found a checkstyle that will check this. Couldn't find a setting with the formatter to do it, unfortunately.

Looks like there might be an outstanding bug regarding Eclipse feature, although this isn't the bug against the formatter, so much as a bug against the cleanup tasks, which is a separate code base. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=322494
Personally I would not like to see a checkstyle rule w/o corresponding automated formatting.

@keith-turner Why not?

In my view, checkstyle's main utility is in identifying style problems which the automatic formatting doesn't cover (either can't, or doesn't yet). If it only enforced stuff our automatic tooling was already doing, it wouldn't be very useful. I've actually been considering trying to make it run faster by having it avoid checks for things that we do automatically, so there's less overlap between the two.

> @keith-turner Why not?

Fatigue.  Sometimes when I have to repeatedly run mvn verify it gets old.  Maybe if maven would find all of the errors and report them in one run it would not be so annoying.  The more checks that are added the more time I potentially spend in the mvn verify loop per change.
@ctubbsii Do you need anything else on this PR?

Also, I don't think the `VERSIONS` file is necessary anymore as you can now just get the version from the jar and this file wasn't kept up to date anyways as the dependencies for this file needed to be updated in the assemble/pom.xml
@ctubbsii, sounds good to me.
@cjmctague At first glance, this looks great!  I am going to checkout your branch and take a closer look today.
@keith-turner I see you merged this, but there was still an unresolved issue in the PR comments above regarding extending the PreferredVolumeChooser.

Hi @byungwok . I'm not sure I fully understand your question, but Accumulo manages lexicographical ordered arbitrary byte arrays. The APIs for String (or CharSequence) parameters are for convenience, and if a character encoding is not provided, it will assume UTF-8 (unless there's a bug that we've overlooked, and then it *may* assume whatever default encoding your local JVM is using).

If you need to scan/delete/insert something with non-printable (binary) characters, you should be able to provide the exact byte array, rather than use any String with a particular encoding.

For convenience, the shell attempts to identify characters which aren't printable and displays them in a hex-encoded format. However, it's not a perfect algorithm... it assumes non-printable, even if your console is capable of printing them, and it may be hard to distinguish between something like the bytes for the literal string `\x00` (a literal backslash, followed by a literal 'x', followed by two literal '0' characters) and the encoded form of a null (0) byte `\x00`. The shell has limitations like this, but you should be able to distinguish between these cases easily using the Java API directly.
@ctubbsii I refactored a bit after that comment, and this chooser is now making use of the methods in PreferredVolumeChooser

There are a few problems with this change :
 
 * Root tablet code assumes all files on one volume. I think these changes could break root tablet when there are multiple volumes.
 * A new tablet directory name is chosen for each new file and I don't think these will ever be garbage collected properly. Ideally tablets would use the same dir name across volumes.   For example a tablet with two files could look like :  `<vol1>/tables/5/t-000000e/F0000002.rf` and `<vol2>/tables/5/t-000000e/F0000003.rf`.  Notice that `t-000000e` is used across volumes.
 * Need to remove directory column from metadata table on upgrade
 * Need to remove code using directory column or repurpose column to contain tablet dir name.
 * Code that cleans up unused tmp files on tablet load may not inspect all volumes.

Addressing these issues would be involved.  If you would like some help making the changes, let me know.  I would like to see this over change made so that tablets can have files on different volumes.

One idea for the directory naming would be to base it on the lock ID for the tserver or if the master creates any sort of logical "session" for assignments, it could use the ID from that. Another idea would be to use process ID. That way, the directory names are "sticky" for lifetime of the tserver process.

I'd prefer not to repurpose the column. It's better to remove to avoid bugs involving code which may assume the old semantics and wasn't properly updated.

For tmp files, we should probably put all those in a well-known directory for each tablet.
I'm not sure this will get Travis happy again... this PR is an attempt to see what happens.
@milleruntime Rebased and squashed into one commit.
For debugging, tmp files (created by in progress compactions), and GC purposes a tablet dir name that is the same for the life of the tablet (and used across volumes) is useful.
Before 1.6 I think the srv:dir column used to only contain the tablet dir name, like `t-000000e`.    In 1.6 it was changed to contain a URI.
The PR jenkins build looks good.  I reran the Travis Hadoop 2 build but it is still dying halfway through.  I don't believe this is related to these changes so I will merge.
Looks good. The TravisCI builds for Accumulo master are failing. I think we should hold off merging this until they are fixed.
I guess it could make sense to go back to that behavior in 1.6, but I think a directory based on the tserver process lifetime is better than putting it in the metadata table.

The 1.6 behavior has the following problem in a multi volume environment.  A tablet created on one volume that is later hosted another volume uses that srv:dir entry to write new files on that original volume and can never be local with the tserver.
Sorry, I meant pre-1.6
Squashed and cherry picked into 1.9.  Than merged forward back into master.
Fixed with 4043c72ab2ad5ba7e984f9ba5cfd961eec66b9bd
The build failures are sporadic so I will merge this.
I can take a look at this.
I saw a bug in your PR. Try again with the updates I pushed to your PR in #675
